title: An Improved Sum Peak Removal Method for EDS Analysis
content: Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (hereafter, EDS) is a microanalytical technique in which X-rays that are generated by an electron beam interacting with a sample in an electron microscope are detected and processed into spectra. Ideally, an EDS spectrum would consist of a background—the Bremsstrahlung (or braking radiation)—and peaks representing the characteristic X-rays from the elements present in the sample. However, depending on a variety of factors, peaks that do not directly represent elemental characteristic X-rays may appear in EDS spectra. Examples of such peaks are escape peaks and sum peaks. These unwanted peaks result from and confound the analysis of both low- and high-Z elements. This paper describes sum peaks, problems with previous methods of sum peak removal, and a new method for sum peak removal.
